vague_description: Determine the optimal allocation of resources to maximize structural capacity under given constraints.
detailed_description: An engineering school has a bridge building competition where students must build as many beam bridges and truss bridges as they can using Popsicle sticks and glue. A beam bridge requires \param{PopsicleBeam} Popsicle sticks and \param{GlueBeam} units of glue while a truss bridge requires \param{PopsicleTruss} Popsicle sticks and \param{GlueTruss} units of glue. Each team has at most \param{TotalPopsicles} Popsicle sticks and \param{TotalGlue} units of glue. In addition, each team can build at most \param{MaxTruss} truss bridges and the number of beam bridges must be larger than the number of truss bridges. If a beam bridge can hold \param{MassBeam} grams and a truss bridge can hold \param{MassTruss} grams, how many of each bridge should a team build to maximize the total mass that can be supported?
target_objective: Maximize the total mass that the built bridges can support
target_constraints: Number of beam bridges is non-negative
Number of truss bridges is non-negative
Total use of Popsicle sticks is at most TotalPopsicles
Total use of glue is at most TotalGlue
At most MaxTruss truss bridges can be built by each team
Number of beam bridges must be greater than the number of truss bridges
target_parameters: Number of Popsicle sticks required for a beam bridge
Units of glue required for a beam bridge
Number of Popsicle sticks required for a truss bridge
Units of glue required for a truss bridge
Mass supported by a beam bridge
Mass supported by a truss bridge
